user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ws_send_frame:
```c
static ssize_t
ws_send_frame (MHD_socket sock, const char *msg, size_t length)
{
  unsigned char *response;
  unsigned char frame[10];
  unsigned char idx_first_rdata;
  size_t idx_response;
  size_t output;
  MHD_socket isock;
  size_t i;

  frame[0] = (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME);
  if (length <= 125)
  {
    frame[1] = length & 0x7F;
    idx_first_rdata = 2;
  }
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 4
  else if (0xFFFF < length)
  {
    frame[1] = 127;
    frame[2] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 56) & 0xFF);
    frame[3] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 48) & 0xFF);
    frame[4] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 40) & 0xFF);
    frame[5] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 32) & 0xFF);
    frame[6] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 24) & 0xFF);
    frame[7] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 16) & 0xFF);
    frame[8] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 8) & 0xFF);
    frame[9] = (unsigned char) (length & 0xFF);
    idx_first_rdata = 10;
  }
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 4 */
  else
  {
    frame[1] = 126;
    frame[2] = (length >> 8) & 0xFF;
    frame[3] = length & 0xFF;
    idx_first_rdata = 4;
  }
  idx_response = 0;
  response = malloc (idx_first_rdata + length + 1);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    return -1;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < idx_first_rdata; i++)
  {
    response[i] = frame[i];
    idx_response++;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < length; i++)
  {
    response[idx_response] = (unsigned char) msg[i];
    idx_response++;
  }
  response[idx_response] = '\0';
  output = 0;
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    isock = CLIENT_SOCKS[i];
    if ((isock != MHD_INVALID_SOCKET) && (isock != sock))
    {
      output += send_all (isock, response, idx_response);
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (response);
  return (ssize_t) output;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function ws_send_frame:
static size_t
send_all (MHD_socket sock, const unsigned char *buf, size_t len)
{
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t off;

  for (off = 0; off < len; off += (size_t) ret)
  {
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
    ret = send (sock, (const void *) &buf[off], len - off, 0);
#else  /* Native W32 */
    ret = send (sock, (const void *) &buf[off], (int) (len - off), 0);
#endif /* Native W32 */
    if (0 > ret)
    {
      if (EAGAIN == errno)
      {
        ret = 0;
        continue;
      }
      break;
    }
    if (0 == ret)
    {
      break;
    }
  }
  return off;
}
...
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct WsData *ws = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = ws->urh;
  unsigned char buf[2048];
  unsigned char *msg;
  char *text;
  ssize_t got;
  int type;
  int i;

  make_blocking (ws->sock);
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (ws->sock, (void *) buf, sizeof (buf), 0);
    if (0 >= got)
    {
      break;
    }
    msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
    if (NULL == msg)
    {
      break;
    }
    if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)
    {
      ssize_t sent;
      int buf_size;
      buf_size = snprintf (NULL, 0, "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg);
      if (0 < buf_size)
      {
        text = malloc ((size_t) buf_size + 1);
        if (NULL != text)
        {
          if (snprintf (text, (size_t) buf_size + 1,
                        "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg) == buf_size)
            sent = ws_send_frame (ws->sock, text, (size_t) buf_size);
          else
            sent = -1;
          free (text);
        }
        else
          sent = -1;
      }
      else
        sent = -1;
      free (msg);
      if (-1 == sent)
      {
        break;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    if (CLIENT_SOCKS[i] == ws->sock)
    {
      CLIENT_SOCKS[i] = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      break;
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (ws);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
...
#define SIZEOF_SIZE_T 8
...
static MHD_socket CLIENT_SOCKS[MAX_CLIENTS]
...
#define MAX_CLIENTS 10
...
#define MHD_INVALID_SOCKET (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any uses of the string.h functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) in the provided code. Therefore there are no direct string.h calls that could cause out-of-bounds accesses under that rule.

Additionally, the relevant buffer/index math in ws_send_frame appears to allocate and index buffers in a way that prevents out-of-bounds accesses:
- The local array frame[10] is only accessed at indices 0..9 (the code writes frame[0], frame[1], and in the 64-bit-size_t branch frame[2]..frame[9]; in the other branch it writes frame[2], frame[3]). These indices are within the 10-byte array.
- response is allocated with malloc(idx_first_rdata + length + 1). The code then writes exactly idx_first_rdata bytes from frame and length bytes from msg, incrementing idx_response accordingly, and finally writes a trailing '\0' at response[idx_response]. The allocation includes the extra +1 byte for that terminator, so those writes are within the allocated buffer.
- send_all iterates using off < len and passes &buf[off] with the remaining length (len - off) to send; it advances off by the number of bytes actually sent (ret). That logic does not call any string.h functions and does not perform pointer arithmetic beyond the bounds determined by len.

Other related operations (snprintf usage to compute buffer size, recv into a local buf[2048]) do not invoke string.h functions either. The only function that could possibly manipulate string memory in the provided excerpts is ws_receive_frame, but its implementation was not provided; it would need to be reviewed separately if it uses string.h functions.

Given the absence of string.h calls in the shown code, there are no fragments to report for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
